caption: Total Corporation ($B)
trend_summary: Total average deposits slightly decreased from $2,012B in 2Q22 to a low of $1,875B in 2Q23, before recovering to $1,910B in 2Q24. The QoQ change in total rate paid (RHS) rose significantly from near 0% in 2Q22 to a peak in 2Q23 and then moderated.

caption: Consumer Banking ($B)
trend_summary: Consumer Banking average deposits declined steadily from $1,078B in 2Q22 to $949B in 2Q24. The QoQ change in total rate paid (RHS) increased from 2Q22, peaked in 2Q23, and has since stabilized.

caption: GWIM ($B)
trend_summary: GWIM average deposits decreased from $364B in 2Q22 to $288B in 2Q24. The QoQ change in total rate paid (RHS) shows a strong upward trend throughout the period, peaking in late 2023.

caption: Global Banking ($B)
trend_summary: Global Banking average deposits fluctuated, starting at $509B in 2Q22, dipping to $493B in 1Q23, and ending at $525B in 2Q24. The QoQ change in total rate paid (RHS) rose sharply from 2Q22 to mid-2023 and has since declined.

caption: 30+ Days Past Due ($MM)
trend_summary: 30+ days past due balances have generally trended upward from 4Q19 to 2Q24. The delinquency rate increased from 2.09% at the start of the period to 2.43% by 2Q24.

caption: 90+ Days Past Due ($MM)
trend_summary: 90+ days past due balances have increased from 4Q19 to 2Q24. The delinquency rate rose from 1.07% in late 2019 to 1.26% in 2Q24.

caption: Payment Rates Remain Elevated while Utilization Rates are Lower Compared to 4Q19
trend_summary: From 4Q19 to 2Q24, the payment rate has remained elevated, ending at 1.2x. The utilization rate has been lower than the 4Q19 baseline, ending at 0.9x.

caption: Growth in Deposit and Investment Balances of Credit Card Clients
trend_summary: The growth in deposit and investment balances of credit card clients has increased significantly, showing a +25% change from the 4Q19 baseline to 2Q24.

caption: Total Loans and Leases ($B)
trend_summary: Total average loans and leases remained relatively stable, fluctuating between $1,046B and $1,051B from 2Q23 to 2Q24, ending at $1,051B, a 0.5% year-over-year increase.

caption: Total Loans and Leases by Portfolio ($B)
trend_summary: From 2Q23 to 2Q24, Commercial loans were relatively flat, ending at $596B. Consumer loans were also stable, starting at $454B and ending at $456B.

caption: Loans and Leases in Business Segments ($B)
trend_summary: From 2Q23 to 2Q24, Consumer Banking loans increased by 2% to $312B. GWIM loans increased by 2% to $223B. Global Banking loans decreased by 3% to $373B. Global Markets loans increased by 5% to $135B.

caption: Total Loans and Leases by Product ($B)
trend_summary: From 2Q23 to 2Q24, U.S. commercial loans increased slightly to $386B. Non-U.S. commercial loans and commercial real estate loans remained stable. Consumer credit card loans decreased slightly to $123B, while home lending and other loans also saw minor decreases.

caption: Net Interest Income (FTE, $B)
trend_summary: Net interest income (GAAP) declined from $14.2B in 2Q23 to $13.7B in 2Q24. Total FTE NII followed a similar trend, falling from $14.3B to $13.9B over the same period.

caption: Net Interest Yield (FTE)
trend_summary: Reported net interest yield declined from 2.06% in 2Q23 to 1.93% in 2Q24. The net interest yield excluding Global Markets also decreased, from 2.65% in 2Q23 to 2.41% in 2Q24.

caption: Net Interest Income excl. GM (FTE, $B)
trend_summary: Net interest income excluding Global Markets (NII excl. GM) decreased from $14.0B in 2Q23 to $13.1B in 2Q24. NII from Global Markets remained relatively stable, fluctuating between $0.3B and $0.8B over the period.

caption: Net Interest Income Outlook
trend_summary: Net interest income is projected to increase from $13.9B in 2Q24 to approximately $14.5B in 4Q24. This outlook is driven by positive impacts from fixed-rate asset repricing (~$300MM), BSBY cessation (~$200MM), day count (~$125MM), and Global Markets NII (~$100MM). These are partially offset by negative impacts from interest rate cuts (~$225MM) and other balance sheet factors (~$50MM-$200MM).

caption: Total Noninterest Expense ($B)
trend_summary: Total noninterest expense was $16.0B in 2Q23, rose to a peak of $17.7B in 4Q23 (including a $2.1B FDIC special assessment), and then settled at $16.3B in 2Q24. Adjusted for the assessment, expense was $15.6B in 4Q23 and $16.5B in 1Q24.

caption: Efficiency Ratio
trend_summary: The efficiency ratio was relatively stable, hovering around 64% in 2Q23, 1Q24, and 2Q24, with a dip to 63% in 3Q23 and a peak of 66% in 4Q23.

caption: Net Charge-offs ($MM)
trend_summary: Net charge-offs increased from $869MM in 2Q23 to $1,533MM in 2Q24. The net charge-off ratio also rose from 0.33% to 0.59% over the same period.

caption: Provision for Credit Losses ($MM)
trend_summary: Provision for credit losses fluctuated, starting at $1,125MM in 2Q23, dipping to $1,104MM in 4Q23, and rising to $1,508MM in 2Q24.

caption: Consumer Net Charge-offs ($MM)
trend_summary: Consumer net charge-offs, primarily driven by credit cards, increased steadily from $720MM in 2Q23 to $1,059MM in 2Q24. The consumer NCO ratio rose from 0.64% to 0.93% over the same period.

caption: Commercial Net Charge-offs ($MM)
trend_summary: Commercial net charge-offs were low in 2Q23 and 3Q23, then rose significantly to $470MM in 1Q24 and $474MM in 2Q24, driven by commercial real estate. The commercial NCO ratio increased from 0.10% in 2Q23 to 0.32% in 2Q24.

caption: Commercial Real Estate as a Percent of:
trend_summary: Commercial real estate as a percentage of total commercial loans decreased from 21.2% in 4Q09 to 11.7% in 2Q24. As a percentage of total loans and leases, it decreased from 6.9% to 6.7% over the same period.

caption: Geographic Distribution ($B)
trend_summary: The geographic distribution of the ~$70B commercial real estate portfolio is led by Northeast (23%, $16.0B), California (20%, $14.1B), and Southeast (17%, $11.9B). Other regions like Midsouth, Southwest, and Midwest each hold smaller shares.

caption: Distribution by Property Type ($B)
trend_summary: The ~$70B commercial real estate portfolio is primarily concentrated in Office (23%, $16.3B), Industrial/Warehouse (21%, $14.7B), and Multi-family rental (16%, $11.6B). Other categories like Hotel/Motels and Shopping centers/Retail hold smaller shares.

caption: Office Portfolio Scheduled Maturities ($B)
trend_summary: Scheduled maturities for the office portfolio are $4.8B in 2H24, $3.7B in 2025, and $4.1B in 2026.

caption: Total Corporation ($B)
trend_summary: Total average deposits increased by 35% from $1,410B in 4Q19 to $1,910B in 2Q24. The composition shifted towards more interest-bearing deposits over the period.

caption: Consumer Banking ($B)
trend_summary: Consumer Banking average deposits increased by 32% from $720B in 4Q19 to $949B in 2Q24, with a notable increase in core operating deposits.

caption: GWIM ($B)
trend_summary: GWIM average deposits increased by 12% from $256B in 4Q19 to $288B in 2Q24. The proportion of sweep deposits has decreased relative to bank deposits.

caption: Global Banking ($B)
trend_summary: Global Banking average deposits grew by 39% from $379B in 4Q19 to $525B in 2Q24, with a significant increase in interest-bearing deposits.

caption: Deposits in Excess of Loans (EOP, $B)
trend_summary: Deposits in excess of loans grew from $451B in 4Q19 to a peak of $1,085B in 4Q21, and have since moderated to $854B in 2Q24.

caption: Cash and Securities Portfolios ($B)
trend_summary: The cash and securities portfolio grew from $634B in 4Q19 to a peak of $1,331B in 4Q21 and stood at $1,199B in 2Q24. HTM securities have decreased since 4Q21, while cash & cash equivalents have increased.

caption: Cash & Securities Yield vs. Deposit Rate Paid
trend_summary: From 4Q19 to 2Q24, both the total deposit rate paid and the cash & securities yield have increased significantly. The yield rose to 3.63% and the deposit rate to 2.03%, with the spread between them widening, especially from 2022 onwards.

caption: Total Revenue ($B)
trend_summary: Total revenue in Consumer Banking remained relatively stable, fluctuating between $10.2B and $10.5B from 2Q23 to 2Q24. Net interest income slightly declined while noninterest income remained steady.

caption: Total Expense ($B) and Efficiency
trend_summary: Total expense fluctuated between $5.2B and $5.5B from 2Q23 to 2Q24. The efficiency ratio remained in a tight range, between 50% and 54%, ending at 54% in 2Q24.

caption: Average Deposits ($B)
trend_summary: Average deposits showed a gradual decline from $1,006B in 2Q23 to $949B in 2Q24, with both core operating and other deposits decreasing.

caption: Average Loans and Leases ($B)
trend_summary: Average loans and leases saw a slight increase from $307B in 2Q23 to $312B in 2Q24, driven by growth in consumer credit card and vehicle lending.

caption: Consumer Investment Assets ($B) and Accounts (MM)
trend_summary: Consumer investment assets grew steadily from $387B in 2Q23 to $476B in 2Q24. The number of accounts also increased from 3.7MM to 3.9MM over the same period.

caption: Consumer Credit Card - New Accounts (K)
trend_summary: New credit card accounts peaked at 1,137K in 2Q23 and subsequently declined to 951K in 2Q24.

caption: Consumer Vehicle Lending - New Originations ($B)
trend_summary: New vehicle lending originations were $6.8B in 2Q23 and 3Q23, then declined to $6.1B in 4Q23 before settling at $6.0B in 2Q24.

caption: Residential Mortgage - New Originations ($B)
trend_summary: New residential mortgage originations fluctuated, starting at $5.9B in 2Q23, dipping to $3.4B in 1Q24, and recovering to $5.7B in 2Q24.

caption: Home Equity - New Originations ($B)
trend_summary: New home equity originations were highest at $2.5B in 2Q23, then trended down to $1.9B in 1Q24, before recovering to $2.4B in 2Q24.

caption: Digital Users and Households
trend_summary: Active digital users grew from 41MM in 2Q21 to 47MM in 2Q24, while verified users grew from 53MM to 58MM. Household adoption increased from 70% to 77% over the same period.

caption: Digital Channel Usage
trend_summary: Digital channel usage (logins) increased from 2,567MM in 2Q21 to 3,466MM in 2Q24. Digital appointments also grew significantly from 796K to 911K over the last two years shown.

caption: Digital Sales
trend_summary: Digital unit sales increased from 1,368K in 2Q22 to 1,659K in 2Q24. Digital sales as a percentage of total sales rose from 44% to 53% in the same period.

caption: Erica Active Users and Interactions (MM)
trend_summary: Erica active users grew steadily from 12.4MM in 2Q21 to 19.6MM in 2Q24. Interactions with Erica also increased, from 94.2MM in 2Q21 to 167.0MM in 2Q24.

caption: Person-to-Person Payments (Zelle)
trend_summary: Zelle active users increased from 14.3MM in 2Q21 to 22.6MM in 2Q24. The volume of transactions grew from 189MM to 382MM, and the value of transactions increased from $57B to $115B over the same period.

caption: Checks vs. Zelle Sent Transactions (MM)
trend_summary: Zelle sent transactions have surpassed checks written, growing to 244MM in 2Q24, while checks written declined to 100MM. The volume of Zelle transactions is now approximately 2.4 times that of checks.

caption: Average Deposits ($B)
trend_summary: Average deposits in Global Wealth & Investment Management remained relatively stable, fluctuating between $288B and $297B from 2Q23 to 2Q24, ending the period at $288B.

caption: Average Loans and Leases ($B)
trend_summary: Average loans and leases increased slightly from $219B in 2Q23 to $223B in 2Q24. This was driven by growth in securities-based lending and consumer real estate, while custom lending and credit card balances remained stable.

caption: Total Revenue ($B)
trend_summary: Total revenue grew from $5.2B in 2Q23 to $5.6B in 2Q24. This growth was primarily driven by an increase in asset management fees, which rose from $2.9B to $3.3B over the period.

caption: Client Balances ($B)
trend_summary: Total client balances increased from $3,635B in 2Q23 to $4,012B in 2Q24. This growth was seen across AUM, Brokerage/other, Deposits, and Loans and leases.

caption: Digital Households / Relationships
trend_summary: The number of digital households/relationships grew from 681K in 2Q21 to 742K in 2Q24. Digital adoption increased from 80% to 85% over the same period.

caption: Digital Channel Adoption
trend_summary: Mobile adoption has steadily increased from 53% in 2Q21 to 62% in 2Q24, while overall online adoption has remained high, fluctuating between 75% and 78%.

caption: eDelivery
trend_summary: eDelivery adoption has consistently grown, increasing from 73% in 2Q21 to 80% in 2Q24.

caption: Erica Interactions (MM)
trend_summary: Interactions with the Erica digital assistant have more than doubled, growing from 1.4 million in 2Q21 to 3.0 million in 2Q24.

caption: Person-to-Person Payments (Zelle)
trend_summary: Zelle transaction volume increased from 1.3MM in 2Q21 to 3.9MM in 2Q24. The corresponding transaction value grew from $0.7B to $2.4B over the same period.

caption: Check Deposits
trend_summary: Automated and digital check deposits have steadily increased their share, rising from 62% in 2Q21 to 67% in 2Q24. Physical check deposits decreased from 1.5MM to 1.2MM over the period.

caption: Average Deposits ($B)
trend_summary: Average deposits in Global Banking grew from $498B in 2Q23 to $525B in 2Q24. The proportion of interest-bearing deposits increased from 58% to 70% over the period.

caption: Average Loans and Leases ($B)
trend_summary: Average loans and leases slightly decreased from $383B in 2Q23 to $373B in 2Q24. The decline was primarily in Corporate and Commercial lending, while Business Banking remained stable.

caption: Total Revenue ($B)
trend_summary: Total revenue in Global Banking fluctuated, starting at $6.5B in 2Q23 and ending at $6.1B in 2Q24. Net interest income decreased over the period, while IB fees and service charges remained relatively stable.

caption: Total Corporation IB Fees ($MM)
trend_summary: Total Corporation IB fees increased from $1,212MM in 2Q23 to $1,561MM in 2Q24. Growth was primarily driven by Debt and Equity underwriting fees.

caption: Business Adoption %
trend_summary: Digital adoption among relationship clients has grown steadily, increasing from 75% in 2Q21 to 87% in 2Q24.

caption: Mobile App Sign-ins (K)
trend_summary: Mobile app sign-ins have shown strong growth, increasing from 727K in 2Q21 to 1,870K in 2Q24.

caption: CashPro App Payments
trend_summary: CashPro app payment value has grown significantly from $84B in 2Q22 to $253B in 2Q24. Payment volume also increased from 2.8MM to 4.0MM over the same period.

caption: Erica Interactions on CashPro Chat (K)
trend_summary: Interactions with Erica on CashPro Chat have been robust since its introduction, with 29.7K interactions recorded in 2Q24.

caption: Proactive Alerts and Insights (MM)
trend_summary: The volume of proactive alerts and insights sent to clients has increased from 17.1MM in 2Q21 to 22.4MM in 2Q24.

caption: Capital Markets Digital Bond Orders (%)
trend_summary: The percentage of U.S. Dollar Investment Grade Debt bond orders processed digitally has grown substantially, from 8% in 2Q22 to 29% in 2Q24.

caption: 2024 YTD Global Markets Revenue Mix (excl. net DVA)
trend_summary: Year-to-date 2024, the Global Markets revenue mix is 63% from U.S. / Canada and 37% from International.

caption: 2024 YTD Total FICC S&T Revenue Mix (excl. net DVA)
trend_summary: Year-to-date 2024, the FICC sales and trading revenue mix is 52% from Macro products (currencies, interest rates, commodities) and 48% from Credit / Other.

caption: Total Sales and Trading Revenue (excl. net DVA) ($B)
trend_summary: Year-to-date total sales and trading revenue has grown from $8.7B in 2021 to $9.9B in 2024. Both FICC and Equities revenue have contributed to this growth, with Equities showing a notable increase in 2024 YTD.

caption: Average Trading-Related Assets ($B) and VaR ($MM)
trend_summary: Average trading-related assets have increased from $534B in 2021 YTD to $635B in 2024 YTD. Average VaR has also risen from $76MM to $85MM over the same period.
